abstracts.cdata!:
The project is rated satisfactory.
            Regardless of success, several lessons emerge. The absence
            of data on the Lake's biodiversity, and productive
            systems, justified research which, in parallel with
            on-the-job training towards building the riparian states
            institutional capacity, was conducted by highly academic,
            and scientific experts. This far sighted decision, provided
            a cadre of scientific personnel, who can now build upon the
            research undertaken, to manage the lake in the future.
            However, it is important to note that the project's
            institutional design stems from weak horizontal linkages
            with national institutions, a most relevant factor to
            scientific findings. These institutions, the Fisheries
            Department, Water Resources Department, and the University
            of Malawi, whose linkages most likely may not reduce the
            long-term impact of the project, may well delay the adequacy
            of the lake's management. Nonetheless, the
            establishment of an environmental monitoring program for the
            maintenance of ecosystems, was a major decision for riparian
            cooperation in the lake's resource management, for it
            lay the foundation to strengthen riparian capacity, in
            preparation of the next phase of the program. However, the
            project reinforces that insufficient preparation of project
            components affects, and delays implementation, for it forces
            management to determine factors whose suitability should
            have been set at appraisal. Likewise, ill defined
            implementing roles, and organizational requirements, should
            have been defined at project preparation.
